channel.title: Best IDE?
channel.description: Hey guys, I've been thinking to get back into C++ to take a break from Java as io9 convinced me to try another language. Anyway, I've been browsing IDE's, but can't make my mind up which is best. I really like SciTE but the output area is incredibly jammed up to the left. Thus making it really hard to read the output.

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

No, Linux all the way semaphore :>

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

My thoughts are slanted due to my having an msdn subscription. I like VS 6 and VS 2005. If you can get over their bloated design (even more bloated than Rational Application Developer (wsad) and current versions of intellij idea).

If you plan on writing windows code (win32, mfc(why?), etc) then I see no reason NOT to use VS unless you simply don’t have the money to get a license/can’t find a free version lying around.

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Not that it’s .NET. That it’s Microsoft.

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:150460”][quote author=lawl link=topic=206025.msg1814401#msg1814401 date=1192006074]

IIRC Dev-C++ uses GCC to compile, not MinGW.

mingw is gcc for windows
[/quote]

That is correct.[/quote]
Oh :embarrassed:
Uhh, in terms of IDE’s, I do like Visual Studio 2005 Express Edition’s features, but of course, there is the whole argument of .NET’s gayness.

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“MastrChief, post:2, topic:150460”]Dev-C++

http://www.bloodshed.net/devcpp.html[/quote]That IDE is terrible. I code in SCiTE and compile with Dev-C++ because I cbf to setup SCiTE.

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Under windows don’t both of them use the same compiler? (being mingw32) If so I don’t see why they would produce different executables, unless you are doing something wrong.

Also linux executables are much smaller than windows executables if thats what you were comparing:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/projects/
tetrislnx32 20K
tetrislnx64 98K
tetriswin32.exe 128K

I used to use KDevelop in linux, and dev-cpp in vmware under windows to compile my c++ programs, but now I have mingw all set up an configured under linux, so KDevelop can compile windows and linux executables in two clicks, imho you just can’t beat that

Read full topic

item.title: Best IDE?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“MastrChief, post:2, topic:150460”]Dev-C++

http://www.bloodshed.net/devcpp.html[/quote]
Doesn’t that compile with a shit load of useless shit? I ran a test last night, my application in SciTE compiled to 2kb, in dev-cpp it went to 428kb I think.

Read full topic
